narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: An introduction to aspects of corporate finance, such as equity/debt, mergers, and leases.
I probably learned more from investopedia than I did from this course.
I learned about corporate finance.

This course gives you the fundamental knowledge to understand what theory underlies the decision of a corporation. Whether its IPOs, capital structure, debt, foreign capital budgeting, discounting and project planning. You'll leave with a better understanding of why corporations function the way they do and why they make the decisions they make e.g paying dividends, preferring to spend cash, debt and issuing equity as a last resort only etc..
How to evaluate firms, exchange currency to calculate NPV, various forms of capital structure maneuvers, debt and equity.
Don't take it. The class itself is good, but the Exams are more about reading interpretation than dominion of the content itself and the TAs are not helpful at all.
Corporate structure, mergers and acquisitions, valuation, future discounting
asset pricing, capital structure and valuation, dividends. Basically tools to understand the structure and financing behind corporations and how valuation/balance sheets are handled.

Through the completion of this course, I have acquired valuable knowledge pertaining to the capital structures of corporations. This includes a deeper understanding of the concepts of debt and equity, as well as the evaluation of stock prices. In terms of skills, I have developed enhanced problem-solving abilities and gained proficiency in balancing balance sheets. Furthermore, I have gained a comprehensive understanding of how financial statements function. One of the highlights of the course was the exposure to numerous captivating real-world cases, which provided valuable insights into the ever-evolving landscape of finance. Overall, this course has equipped me with valuable knowledge, practical skills, and insightful perspectives, enabling me to navigate the complexities of corporate finance with confidence.
Corporate finance (capital structure mostly)
Basic knowledge of finance that I needed, very useful.
A lot

Utilization of different corporate finance principles and important equations in order to answer long questions based on case studies. We were expected to be able to answer questions similar to those set at HBS, learning the whole textbook of corporate finance principles without any prerequisite knowledge of terms and concepts (saying that ECON 121 and ECON 117 were prerequisites was also a fallacy, as they were not relevant to the course).
How to approach financial evaluation
Learning how to use critical thinking to apply class concepts to the tests.
You learn about economics in relation to the finance industry. There also were a few case studies to help tie the material taught in the course to the real world.
Nothing. Terrible class.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: very disorganized, slides were old, a lot of unclear directions on each slide

Strengths: low workload
Weaknesses: poor teaching (disconnect between the professor and the students, low attendance as a result), in a corporate finance class I hoped to examine more real life examples rather than being shown various random formulas without context.

Strengths: good content and lots of continuity in lecture Weaknesses: lecture slides are way too long and lots of students get lost in the weeds of mathematical theory that aren't even tested or really relevant in the applications later on
Exams much harder than psets
There was a lot of math but not a lot of practice, and in class, the math problems wouldn't actually be done by hand and would only show up in the slides.
Assessed on application that unfortunately barely gets walked through in lecture. Content is solid and Prof Clayton is very engaging, but the assessment is poor.

The strength is definitely in the material and the way it was taught by Professor Clayton. I found the lectures and the concepts learned interesting. The course can be a bit too theoretical at times with no real practical applications but this got better toward the second half of the course as topics were more centered around numbers and making quantitative analyses. I felt that the exams were way harder and ambiguous than they needed to be. I left both the midterm and final not being very sure whether if what I'd put down was right, which was the same for pretty much all of the class.
Lectures could tie more closely to the types of problems that are on problem sets and exams. Lectures could also tie concepts and equations more closely to case studies.
The subject of the course is very applicable for those who want to go to Investment Banking or Consulting, but the final exam was very hard, far from what we were able to prepare for.
I can honestly not think of any strengths for this class. There was very low engagement across the board and the lecture material was often dense and not engaging.

This course offers several strengths that contribute to a comprehensive learning experience. It covers a wide range of topics within the syllabus, providing a thorough understanding of corporate finance. The workload is relatively low, with only four problem sets graded on completion, allowing for a manageable pace of learning. Additionally, the instructor's jovial disposition creates a positive and engaging learning environment. However, there are certain weaknesses that could be addressed for further improvement. The exams are significantly more challenging than the practice exams and do not closely resemble the homework assignments, which can create difficulties for students. The qualitative nature of the slides could be enhanced with more quantitative content to better assist with completing homework and preparing for exams. Lastly, the instructor's approach of covering too many topics in a single lecture may lead to difficulty in concentration and potential disengagement among students. Addressing these weaknesses by aligning exams with practice materials, providing more quantitative slide content, and structuring lectures to focus on a single topic at a time would enhance the course's effectiveness and improve the overall learning experience.
Could be less theoretical and more practical

Lectures can be made more clear, more
Practice questions in the slides.

you learn very comprehensive theories about finance. a weakness is there isnt much time in class to go through word problems found in problem sets/exams; it would be helpful if there is some time allotted to that. also, sometimes the slides arent the most consistent (typos, not updated cut-off points for slides that are too long).
Great course

Strengths: Very little unfortunately, I felt I could learn so much more from reading a textbook, speaking to my parents, or even watching a short video.
Improvements: This course couldve been so much better if it was taken far slower and covered less material, but with a lot more focus given to the core concepts. Also, section were almost pointless as the TA did not know the concepts, and OH were only attended because we wanted the problem set answers (which therefore were also only useful during review).
I don't think the class lined up with the psets super well, especially on the 2nd set
More practice! Whether it be more psets or another midterm, I needed to be more engaged, and it was hard to be with a pset once a month.
The course is extremely technical, prior knowledge of corporate finance is required to understand the material presented in class. Would not recommend if not familiar with the material already.
There need to be weekly problem sets. With so few problem sets, students this semester had little inventive to learn weekly content.

The course os very. lackluster and leaves little to not room for student engagement, making it  incredibly hard to sit through. But the topics discussed are interesting in theory like Bankruptcy, M&A dealings.
Really sweet professor but very dry and boring material. Nothing like practical accounting or finance. Much worse than ECON 251.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Do not take this class thinking its going to prepare you for banking or finance.
Yes, but only if they are interested in the underlying reasons why corporations make the decisions they do - which everyone should be!
Yes if they enjoy learning about finance.
Probably not. There are probably better ways to learn about corporate finance than by taking this course.

Lots of theory behind more basic technicals that one would learn to prep for IB or other finance interviews (DCF, CAPM, LBOs, IPOs). If that interests you, then I'd recommend this class with the goal of C/D/F given how absurdly difficult the final was (it was not at all a reflection of what we had learned on psets and the past practice exams we were given) and with a mindset to learn.
Absolutely not.

It is an interesting economics elective that I think would be worth taking if you are interested in or plan to venture into finance at some point. I would highly recommend taking Financial Economic (ECON 251) before this course because it serves as a great set up to the skills and concepts you'll need to use at some points in this class as well. I would recommend with cautionary advice about how the material can be very theoretical and not directly applicable to what you'll see in real world finance. That aside, you get to learn some interesting things about how corporations work and their overall structure that you would not be able to learn otherwise.
For students interested in finance, this is a good course.
No. Don't take it. Just study CorpFin by yourself and spend a credit on something more interesting/ a class that actually facilitates student learning.
No

No. If you are planning to take this as an econ elective, please look for another one. Many people will say that it is an easy class with a generous curve and while that is true, it is simply not worth it. You are much better off taking an interesting class and putting in a bit more work instead of taking this class and having to force yourself to find it interesting. If you are actually interested in corporate finance, knock yourself out. Prof. Clayton is very nice, so that is a plus.

Based on the strengths and weaknesses identified, I highly recommend this course, especially for students interested in pursuing a career in finance without prior knowledge in the field. The course covers a wide syllabus, providing a comprehensive understanding of corporate finance, while maintaining a manageable workload with only four problem sets graded on completion. The instructor's enthusiastic and jolly demeanor contributes to an enjoyable learning environment. Although there are weaknesses, such as the challenging exams that differ from practice materials and the qualitative nature of the slides, these can be addressed. Considering the valuable insights and practical skills gained from the course, it is an essential choice for individuals seeking to enter the finance industry.
Yes if you have an investment banking job. Not if youre applying. Pretty useless for interviews.
Yes, it's great

No. You can see the potential and utility in learning the material from this course, but not in this way whatsoever. As I said, one could easily (and indeed I felt like I had to) learn much more from reading the textbook themselves and watching videos / being taught by family friends.
Only if interested in a career in finance.
I would not recommend this course to someone who is looking for a first exposure to corporate finance, it is very technical and the lectures assume a lot of prior knowledge.
I would not, unless weekly problem sets are put in place.

No, the lectures were so boring. You could easily have chosen to not attend the lectures and still have passed the class, especially considering barely anything taught in lectures were on the exams. Also the TAs were little to no help so it really sucked.
Gut and easy grading but very dry.
